message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is confirmed by the enlarged prostate on rectal exam. The weak urinary stream and prolonged dribbling suggest obstructive symptoms. Terazosin is a medication used to reduce BPH-related symptoms by relaxing smooth muscles in the prostate and bladder neck. Bladder catheterization is not necessary in this case as the patient is still able to urinate on his own. Finasteride therapy is used to reduce the size of the prostate in patients with BPH but is not the first-line treatment for symptom relief. Cystoscopy is not necessary for diagnosis in this case as the patient’s symptoms, physical exam findings, and postvoid ultrasound results are consistent with BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and enlarged prostate suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin is an alpha-blocker that relaxes the smooth muscle in the prostate and improves urine flow in patients with BPH. Bladder catheterization is not necessary as the patient is able to void, and finasteride therapy is not appropriate as the patient’s prostate-specific antigen is within the reference range. Cystoscopy may be considered if there are other concerns or if the patient does not respond to initial therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and enlarged prostate suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin is an alpha-blocker that helps with BPH symptoms by relaxing smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, thereby increasing urine flow rate and reducing symptoms. Bladder catheterization is invasive and should only be considered if there is acute urinary retention. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that can help reduce the size of the prostate but may take months to be effective. Cystoscopy is not needed at this point.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and the enlarged prostate confirmed by rectal exam. The most appropriate next step in management is terazosin therapy, which is an alpha-1 blocker that can improve urinary symptoms associated with BPH. Bladder catheterization is not necessary at this point, and finasteride therapy or cystoscopy may be considered later as second-line or diagnostic options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and prostate exam suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin, an alpha-adrenergic blocker, is commonly used for BPH treatment to alleviate symptoms such as urinary obstruction and frequent urination. Catheterization is not necessary unless there is acute urinary retention. Finasteride, a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor, can also be used for BPH treatment, but it takes longer to show effects. Cystoscopy may be necessary if there is suspicion of other underlying conditions like bladder cancer but is not the initial step in management for a patient with BPH.

Bladder catheterization is not necessary since the patient is able to urinate on his own, and there is no indication for cystoscopy or finasteride therapy at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is confirmed by the smooth, enlarged prostate. Terazosin is an alpha-blocker that can relieve the symptoms of BPH by relaxing smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urinary flow. Bladder catheterization is not necessary as the patient is able to urinate, although with difficulty. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that can reduce the size of the prostate over time, but it may take several months to see the effects. Cystoscopy is not indicated at this point.

The symptoms and examination findings suggest Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH), and alpha-blockers such as terazosin are first-line therapy for mild to moderate BPH symptoms. Bladder catheterization is not indicated as the patient can still void on his own. Finasteride is used in patients with enlarged prostate and higher PSA levels. Cystoscopy is not necessary at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and enlarged prostate suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin is an alpha-blocker that relaxes the smooth muscle in the prostate and allows easier urine flow. Bladder catheterization is not necessary at this point and Finasteride therapy is used to reduce the size of the prostate. Cystoscopy may be considered if there are other concerning findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and the enlarged prostate on rectal exam confirms this. Bladder catheterization may be necessary if there is acute urinary retention, but it's not the first choice for management. Finasteride therapy is appropriate for BPH with a large prostate, but it won't help with the patients' urinary symptoms or residual bladder volume. Cystoscopy may be necessary if there are other concerning symptoms or if the patient does not respond to initial therapy. Terazosin therapy is appropriate for BPH with urinary symptoms, and it is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient.
